Problem:
Consider a function defined by \\( f(z) = \\int_0^\\infty e^{-st} z(t) dt \\), which is a Laplace transform of the function \\( z(t) \\). Assume \\( z(t) \\) satisfies the differential equation \\( \\dot{z} = Mz \\) where M is a constant matrix. Let an intervention be defined as a multiplication by matrix \\( P \\) at time t = 0.

If the intervention defined by matrix \\( P \\) is applied at t=0 before \\( z(t) \\) evolves according to \\( \\dot{z} = Mz \\), will the transformed function \\( f(z) \\) reflect only the effects of the matrix M regardless of P?
Explanation: The intervention with matrix \\( P \\) changes the initial state of \\( z(t) \\) to \\( Pz(0) \\). This modified initial condition will influence the future state trajectory under \\( \\dot{z} = Mz \\) and hence also alter the outcome of the Laplace transformation \\( f(z) \\). The effect of P cannot be disregarded.
